title: Area of a Circle
content:
The most fundamental formula in geometry:

$$A = \pi r^2$$

**Wiedijk #9** on the list of 100 famous theorems.

**Historical note**: Archimedes proved this around 250 BCE using the **method of exhaustion** — an ancient precursor to calculus.

title: Main Theorem
content:
**Area of a Circle (Wiedijk #9)**:

$$\text{volume}(\text{ball}(c, r)) = \pi r^2$$

The proof is a **one-liner** — just applying Mathlib's `Complex.volume_ball`! This shows the power of building on a library.

title: Special Cases
content:
**Special cases**:

- **Unit disk** (r = 1): Area = π
- **Zero radius**: Area = 0 (empty ball)
- **Closed vs open disk**: Same area — the boundary (circle) has measure 0
- **Negative radius**: Empty set, area = 0

title: Archimedes' Insight
content:
Archimedes imagined the disk as **concentric thin rings**:

$$dA = 2\pi\rho\, d\rho$$

Integrating:
$$A = \int_0^r 2\pi\rho\, d\rho = \pi r^2$$

This is calculus **2000 years** before Newton and Leibniz!
